description: From Middle English grope, grupe, groupe, from Old English grōp (“ditch”), from Proto-Germanic *grōpō (“furrow, ditch, trench”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰreb-, *gʰrebʰ- (“to dig, furrow, scratch”). Cognate with Scots gruip (“gutter, drain, ditch, trench”), North Frisian groop (“pit”), Dutch groep (“a trench, moat”), Swedish grop (“a pit, ditch, hole, hollow”), Old English grēp, grēpe (“land-drain, ditch; furrow; burrow; privy”). More at grip, groove.

entries.meaning: (obsolete or UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) A trench or small ditch.
(obsolete or UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) A trench or drain; particularly, a trench or hollow behind the stalls of cows or horses for receiving their dung and urine.
examples: Cleaning the byre involved barrowing out the contents of the groop, sluicing it down and rebedding it with clean straw.

entries.meaning: (obsolete or UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) A pen for cattle; a byre.

verbs.description: groop (third-person singular simple present groops, present participle grooping, simple past and past participle grooped)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To make a channel or groove; to form grooves.

description: Alteration of group. More at group.

verbs.description: groop (third-person singular simple present groops, present participle grooping, simple past and past participle grooped)
